newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee ends sharply up on stocks, Colombia.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee ends sharply up on stocks, Colombia.

text.p: Robusta coffee futures retained sharp gains by the close on funds and arbitrage buying, inspired by the surprisingly large draw in U.S. certified stocks.
Traders said growing worries over Colombian supplies following a prolonged strike by truck drivers also lent a bullish tone to the market.
"The Colombian strike news is obviously more important to the market than the certifieds," said one trader.
Origin selling seemed to have dried up as producers waited for much-higher levels while roasters were well-covered in the nearbys, traders said,

The most-active November/January spread, a barometer of nearby supply availability, stood at $122 at the close after touching a high of $143, as funds sold January to cover their short positions in November.
Heavily-traded January closed $40 higher at $1,427 a tonne while front-month November firmed $49 at $1,549.
The day's volume, dominated by the Nov/Jan switch, totalled 9,202 lots at the finish.
U.S. certified stocks fell 24,391 60-kg bags in the week ended October 18 to 5,583 bags, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange said on Monday.
But what was seen as more bullish is that no coffee was pending certification, greatly diminishing chances for a build in stocks next week.
Some traders said the strong market reaction to the stock news could be more psychological than anything.

"The numbers are meaningless. If the market trades about 100 million bags a year, then 25,000 bags don't really make a big difference," said one. Traders said the market was closely watching the situation in key grower Colombia after a week-old truck drivers' strike was said to have halted exports.

The country's coffee chief Jorge Cardenas said on Tuesday the strike had paralysed the nation's coffee industry and forced delays in the shipment of about 250,000 60-kg bags of coffee promised for delivery in October.
